_header: To very God and to all true in Christ
Note:
Cf. Reply by Friar Daw Tobias (6562), suggested by Skeat to be in prose. Also cf. Jack Upland’s Rejoinder (2778); non-source-specific editions are Speght (1602)
XSpeght, Thomas. The Workes of…Geffrey Chaucer. London, [A. Islip,] imp. G. Bishop, 1598; rev. ed. A. Islip, 1602 (STC 5077, 5080), ff. 348-350v (which is ed. Wright (1859)
XWright, Thomas. Political Poems and Songs relating to English History, composed during the period From the Accession of Edward III to that of Richard III. 2 vols. Rolls Series 14 (1859, 1861); repr. Kraus, 1965, 2.16); Urry (1721)
XUrry, John. The Works of Geoffrey Chaucer. London: B. Lintot, 1721, 500; Townshend (1843)
XTownshend, George. The Acts and Monuments of John Foxe…. London: Seeley, Burnside, and Seeley, 1843-49, 2.357; Sibbald (1802)
XSibbald, John. Chronicle of Scottish Poetry…. 4 vols. Edinburgh and London, 1802, 2.31-33 (extracts); Dean (1991)
XDean, James M. Six Ecclesiastical Satires. Kalamazoo, MI: Western Michigan University for TEAMS, 1991.
_description: Jack Upland — in very rough alliterative verse

CULFf62.Editions:
Heyworth,  Peter L.,
                        ed.  
             Jack Upland, Friar Daw’s Reply, and Upland’s
                Rejoinder.
         Oxford: OUP, 1968: (crit. ed.).

BLHar6641.First Lines:
To veri god & to alle trewe in cristI Iacke vplonde make my
                    moone þat anticrist…
BLHar6641.Last Lines:
…& whanne ȝe asoilen þat I haue seide sadli
                    intruþe I schal asoile þee of þin ordre & saue þee
                    to heuene
BLHar6641.Editions:
Heyworth,  Peter L.,
                        ed.  
             Jack Upland, Friar Daw’s Reply, and Upland’s
                Rejoinder.
         Oxford: OUP, 1968: (crit. ed.).
